answers.answer: The most common cause of mild to moderate elevations of liver enzymes is fatty liver. In the United States, the most frequent cause of fatty liver is alcohol abuse. Other causes of fatty liver include diabetes mellitus and obesity. Chronic hepatitis C is also an an important cause of mild to moderate liver enzyme elevations.  Liver damage inflicted by toxins as from an overdose of acetaminophen (brand-name Tylenol)can be a cause, but I think your numbers would be much higher.  Go get some tests.

Hi and welcome! Have you had a bx yet? If you do have hep c, I would see about finding a hepatologist, if you do have hep c. I definately would go for a biopsy. Best wishes and keep us informed. Love and prayers, Cindee

In response to your high enzymes, I'm a 53 yr old F recently diagnosed with HepC Genotype 2b w/AST-368,ALT-718.  Went to specialist & he's strangely puzzled at my high levels. Wanted to wait another 6 weeks & test again before discussing bx or tx.  I've changed doctors b/c of his seemingly lack of interest. Don't those levels seem alarming to y'all?

question: i received blood tests results yesterday and my physician has sent me to a liver specialist. I am a 33 year old female and my ast # is 108 should be at 40 and my alt # is 215 and it should be 40.  I don't drink except of a glass of wine on the weekends, but I do take ibuprofen.  Any reason that you can think of that my levels would be this high?
title: high ast and alt
